node.title: ShouldApply
node.bodyText: Does the ShouldApply() clause still work with DirichletBCs? It still works with PenaltyDirichletBCs. However, when using the new computeQpValue() method DirichletBCs seem to have an issue of trying to both set and not set the boundary condition when should apply is false, and it produces a displacement that is neither 0 (the value if the BC is disabled) or the intended value when the BC is active. If you use the older computeQpResidual() it has convergence issues that seem similar to the results from setting use_preset = false.

Hello
It should. shouldApply is defined in the BoundaryCondition parent class.

and it produces a displacement that is neither 0 (the value if the BC is disabled)

Why would it be 0 if the BC is disabled? 0 could be imposed with a DirichletBC but how do you know it is 0 if it's not imposed?

If you use the older computeQpResidual() it has convergence issues that seem similar to the results from setting use_preset = false.

ComputeQpResidual is set by the DirichletBCBase to (u - value). What are you modifying it to?

That BC is the only source of displacement in the simulation at present. When the BC is removed from the input file the displacement is zero and there are no other BCs on the surface.
I've left it at _u[_qp] - value at the moment, but it still has this issue. However, it is good to know shouldapply is supposed to still work.

Ok I think I got it. When using a DirichletBC with shouldapply and computeQpValue(), at the beginning of each timestep it is trying to set the surface to the value if the BC is active and then work towards to an inactive condition. If the value is similar to what would happen if there was no BC this works, but if not then it's a problem.

node.title: An error occurred when using MeshModifiers and Pressure
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
When I used MeshModifiers, and set the Pressure boundary condition, I got the following error:
*** ERROR ***
'Pressure_load_0' of type 'Pressure' depends on variable(s) 'disp_x,disp_y,disp_z'. However, that variable does not appear to be defined on (all of) boundary 'top'.

My input file is ‘test1.i’ below. Is there a way to solve this problem?

test1.i
[Problem]
  kernel_coverage_check = false
  material_coverage_check = false
  boundary_restricted_node_integrity_check = false
[]

new_domain_blocks = '1001	1002'

[Mesh]
  [box]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 3
    nx = 10
    ny = 10
    nz = 10
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 1
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 1
    zmin = 0
    zmax = 1
  []
  [box1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = box
    block_id = 1
    bottom_left = '0 0.5 0'
    top_right = '1 1 1'
  []

  add_subdomain_ids = '${new_domain_blocks}'
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]

[Variables]
  [disp_x]
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
  []
  [disp_y]
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
  []
  [disp_z]
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
  []
[]

[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]
  [./all]
    strain = finite
    add_variables = false
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [Gravity1]
    type = Gravity
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
    use_displaced_mesh = false
    variable = disp_y
    value = -10
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [zhouya]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0  500 1000'
    y = '0  0   1e6'
  []
[]

# ===== Boundary Conditions =====
[BCs]
  [archor_x]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'bottom'
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []

  [archor_y]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'bottom'
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []

  [archor_z]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'bottom'
    variable = disp_z
    value = 0
  []

  [Pressure]
    [load]
      boundary = 'top'
      function = 'zhouya'
    []
  []
[]

# ===== Materials (linear-elastic to keep it simple) =====
[Materials]
  [elasticity_tensor1]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
    youngs_modulus = 50E6 # 50 MPa
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
  []

  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
  []

  [density1]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    block = '${new_domain_blocks}'
    prop_names = density
    prop_values = 2000
  []
[]

[MeshModifiers]
  [m1]
    type = TimedSubdomainModifier
    times = '200 300'
    blocks_from = '0	1'
    blocks_to = '1001	1002'
  []
[]

# ===== Executioner =====
[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  automatic_scaling = true

  end_time = 1000
  dt = 100

  solve_type = 'PJFNK'

  nl_abs_tol = 1E-5
  nl_max_its = 400

  l_tol = 1E-8
  l_max_its = 200
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

Hello
So 'top' is not connected to the domains where the displacements are being solved for.
Is this intentional?
You could define the displacements everywhere on the domain, then use a NullKernel on the domains where you are not solving the solid mechanics equations for yet.
Otherwise, you will need to turn off the other integrity check for nodal variables and BCs
Guillaume

So 'top' is not connected to the domains where the displacements are being solved for. Is this intentional?

It wasn't my intention.

You could define the displacements everywhere on the domain, then use a NullKernel on the domains where you are not solving the solid mechanics equations for yet.

I was trying to simulate the construction. If I define displacement on all domains and use NullKernel, the unconstructed regions will also be displaced.

Otherwise, you will need to turn off the other integrity check for nodal variables and BCs

I tried to turn off 'boundary_restricted_elem_integrity_check', but it had the following error.
Time Step 0, time = 0

Time Step 1, time = 100, dt = 100

Performing automatic scaling calculation

Segmentation fault (core dumped)

ok the integrity check is there for a reason. Consider this is not supported.
I would recommend trying the no-restriction + null kernel approach

If I define displacement on all domains and use NullKernel on subdomains that are not activated. Then the inactive subfields will also be deformed. As shown in the image below:

This is also the case when setting DirichletBC on the 'bottom' boundary. The problem is resolved when 'boundary_restricted_node_integrity_check' is turned off.

The problem is resolved when 'boundary_restricted_node_integrity_check' is turned off.

This should not be. It s just a diagnostic to make sure the nodal BCs are applied on surfaces on which the variable is defined.

Then the inactive subfields will also be deformed

Are they deformed or just translated?

node.title: Restarting with checkpoints : huge generated data, procs number
node.bodyText:
Hello,
In the "Small Strain" framework, we typically restart jobs by utilizing the [UserObjects] block or by prescribing initial conditions (IC) on the desired variables. However, this approach has not been feasible in the "Finite Strain" framework, and we are unclear why it's impossible to apply an IC condition in this context.
To address this, we have switched to using checkpoints for restarting jobs. This method, however, results in the creation of numerous large subfolders  and several gigabytes of data. Additionally, a limitation we've encountered is the inability to change the number of processors (procs) between the initial job and the restart—running the first job with X procs means we must use the same number for subsequent jobs.
We have reviewed the "Restart and Recover" documentation but have not found an effective solution to these issues. Could you please provide guidance on how to reduce the volume of generated data and advise on a strategy to run jobs with varying numbers of procs?
Thank you for your assistance.
Could anyone help in explaining to us why it is not possible to apply IC in  solid mechanics within the   "finite strain" assumption ?

ICs are for variables. You need to be restarting stresses iirc, which are material properties
Checkpoints are the correct way to restart these simulations.

You could alternatively try applying an eigenstrain at the start of the simulation, although depending on your strain field "your mileage may vary". @dewenyushu may have some additional insights, if the initial stress method @GiudGiud suggested will not work for your case

While we have successfully resolved our issue using checkpoints, we still lack clarity on why initial conditions (ICs) fail to function as expected. For any given prescribed displacement, the solver is supposed to iterate until it converges. This is not happening in our case. It only works in "small strain".

Could you please provide guidance on how to reduce the volume of generated data and advise on a strategy to run jobs with varying numbers of procs?

You can set the number of checkpoint files to 1 instead of 2 to reduce the amount of data by a factor of 2.
Jobs with varying number of procs wont be supported with checkpoints.

we still lack clarity on why initial conditions (ICs) fail to function as expected

The finite strain approach is relying on this object right?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ADComputeFiniteStrain.html
If so that's a stateful material property, which ICs cannot restart.

[free_energy_A]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = Fa
    coupled_variables = 'c'
    expression = '(c-0.1)^2'
    derivative_order = 2
    enable_jit = true
[]
[free_energy_B]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = Fb
    coupled_variables = 'c'
    expression = '(c-0.9)^2'
    derivative_order = 2
    enable_jit = true
[]
[nucleation]
    # The nucleation material is configured to insert nuclei into the free energy
    # tht force the concentration to go to 0.95, and holds this enforcement for 500
    # time units.
    type = DiscreteNucleation
    property_name = Fn
    op_names  = eta3
    op_values = 0.90
    map = map
    outputs = exodus
[]
[free_energy_nuc]
    # add the chemical and nucleation free energy contributions together
    type = DerivativeSumMaterial
    derivative_order = 2
    coupled_variables = 'eta3 c'
    sum_materials = 'Fa Fn'
    property_name = Fan
[]

# h(eta)
[h0]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMaterial
    h_order = HIGH
    eta = eta0
    function_name = h0
[]
[h1]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMaterial
    h_order = HIGH
    eta = eta1
    function_name = h1
[]
[h2]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMaterial
    h_order = HIGH
    eta = eta2
    function_name = h2
[]
[h3]
    type = SwitchingFunctionMaterial
    h_order = HIGH
    eta = eta3
    function_name = h3
[]
# g(eta)
[barrier]
    type = MultiBarrierFunctionMaterial
    etas = 'eta0 eta1 eta2 eta3'
[]

# constant properties
[constants]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'M   L   kappa_eta kappa_c'
    prop_values = '0.1 2 1 1'
[]

[free_energy]
    type = DerivativeMultiPhaseMaterial
    property_name = F
    fi_names = 'Fa Fb Fb Fan' # free energy from thermodynamic database
    hi_names = 'h0  h1 h2 h3'
    etas     = 'eta0 eta1 eta2 eta3'
    coupled_variables = 'c'
    W = 1
[]
[]

[Kernels]
[eta_force]
    type = DiscreteNucleationForce
    variable = eta3
    map = map
    no_nucleus_value = 0
    nucleus_value = 0.9
[]
[eta_react]
    type = Reaction
    variable = eta3
[]
[c_res]
    type = SplitCHParsed
    variable = c
    f_name = F
    kappa_name = kappa_c
    w = w
    coupled_variables = 'eta0 eta1 eta2 eta3'
[]
[w_res]
    type = SplitCHWRes
    variable = w
    mob_name = M
[]
[time1]
    type = CoupledTimeDerivative
    variable = w
    v = c
[]

# Allen Cahn for eta_s
[deta0dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta0
[]
[ACBulk0]
    type = AllenCahn
    variable = eta0
    coupled_variables = 'c eta1 eta2 eta3'
    f_name = F
[]
[ACInterface0]
    type = ACInterface
    variable = eta0
    coupled_variables = 'eta1 eta2 eta3'
    kappa_name = kappa_eta
[]
[lagrange0]
    type = SwitchingFunctionConstraintEta
    variable = eta0
    h_name   = h0
    lambda = lambda
    coupled_variables = 'eta1 eta2 eta3'
[]

#
[deta1dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta1
[]
[ACBulk1]
    type = AllenCahn
    variable = eta1
    coupled_variables = 'c eta0 eta2 eta3'
    f_name = F
[]
[ACInterface1]
    type = ACInterface
    variable = eta1
    kappa_name = kappa_eta
    coupled_variables = 'eta0 eta2 eta3'
[]
[lagrange1]
    type = SwitchingFunctionConstraintEta
    variable = eta1
    h_name   = h1
    lambda = lambda
    coupled_variables = 'eta0 eta2 eta3'
[]

#
[deta2dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta2
[]
[ACBulk2]
    type = AllenCahn
    variable = eta2
    coupled_variables = 'c eta0 eta1 eta3'
    f_name = F
[]
[ACInterface2]
    type = ACInterface
    variable = eta2
    kappa_name = kappa_eta
    coupled_variables = 'eta0 eta1 eta3'
[]
[lagrange2]
    type = SwitchingFunctionConstraintEta
    variable = eta2
    h_name   = h2
    lambda = lambda
    coupled_variables = 'eta1 eta0 eta3'
[]

#
[deta3dt]
    type = TimeDerivative
    variable = eta3
[]
[ACBulk3]
    type = AllenCahn
    variable = eta3
    coupled_variables = 'c eta0 eta1 eta2'
    f_name = F
[]
[ACInterface3]
    type = ACInterface
    variable = eta3
    kappa_name = kappa_eta
    coupled_variables = 'eta0 eta1 eta2'
[]
[lagrange3]
    type = SwitchingFunctionConstraintEta
    variable = eta3
    h_name   = h3
    lambda = lambda
    coupled_variables = 'eta1 eta2 eta0'
[]

[lagrange]
    type = SwitchingFunctionConstraintLagrange
    variable = lambda
    etas    = 'eta0 eta1 eta2 eta3'
    h_names = 'h0   h1 h2 h3'
    epsilon = 1e-6
[]
[]

[Preconditioning]
[SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
[]
[]

[Executioner]
    type = Transient
    scheme = 'bdf2'

    solve_type = 'NEWTON'      
    line_search = none

    l_max_its = 15
    l_tol = 1.0e-6

    nl_max_its = 50
    nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-8
    nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-10

    start_time = 0.0
    num_steps = 1000
    dt = 0.1
    #dtmin = 0.01
[]

[Debug]
    # show_var_residual_norms = true
[]

[Outputs]
    execute_on = 'timestep_end'

node.title: Large flunctuations of velocities on the fixed boundary
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
I am conducting large deformation elastodynamics simulations involving a compressive wave propagating from the left end of a bar. At the left boundary, I apply a displacement boundary condition that ramps up to a fixed displacement value, holding it constant afterward.
While the displacement profile appears correct, I am observing significant fluctuations in the velocity at the left boundary. I expected these velocities to remain relatively small due to the fixed displacement condition following the ramp-up phase. Could these fluctuations be attributed to numerical artifacts, or are there other potential causes for this behavior?
Thank you for any insights.
animation of disp_x and vel_x:

  
    
    

    disp_vel.mp4
    
  

  

  


my input file:

hht_alpha = -0.00
beta = '${fparse (1-hht_alpha)^2/4}'
gamma = '${fparse 1/2-hht_alpha}'

    type = FileMeshGenerator
    file = './mesh/bar.msh'
  []
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  alpha = ${hht_alpha}
  beta = ${beta}
  gamma = ${gamma}
  large_kinematics = true
  use_displaced_mesh = false
[]

  [disp_y]
  []
  [disp_z]
  []
[]

  []
  [accel_z]
  []
  [vel_z]
  []
  [stress_xx]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
    [AuxKernel]
      type = RankTwoAux
      rank_two_tensor = cauchy_stress
      index_i = 0
      index_j = 0
      execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_END'
    []
  []
[]

[Kernels]
  [solid_x]
    type = TotalLagrangianStressDivergence
    variable = disp_x
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    component = 0
  []
  [inertia_x] # M*accel + eta*M*vel

    velocity = vel_x
    acceleration = accel_x
    density = density
  []
  [solid_y]

    component = 1
  []
  [inertia_y] # M*accel + eta*M*vel

    velocity = vel_y
    acceleration = accel_y
    density = density
  []

    displacement = disp_x
    velocity = vel_x

  []
  [vel_x] # Calculates and stores velocity at the end of the time step
    type = NewmarkVelAux
    variable = vel_x
    acceleration = accel_x
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [accel_y] # Calculates and stores acceleration at the end of time step
    type = NewmarkAccelAux
    variable = accel_y
    displacement = disp_y
    velocity = vel_y
    execute_on = timestep_end
  []
  [vel_y] # Calculates and stores velocity at the end of the time step

  l_tol = 1e-6
  # r_tol = 1e-6
  # nl_max_its = 20
  nl_max_its = 500
  l_max_its = 500
  line_search = None
  [TimeIntegrator]
    type = NewmarkBeta
    inactive_tsteps = 1
  []
  []

This is very similar to this thread: #22574
I believe it would be fixed with ramping up your BC or applying an initial condition on your velocity.
I will try with IC on velocity
humm, the displacement boundary is indeed ramped up from 0 to maximum value using an exponential function, and I tried to set initial velocity to 0, but still see those fluctuations.

If there is no change to your problem definition, I believe you will have these artifacts.
Look at the velocity of your disp bc, if you take the derivative at 0, the velocity is close to 1. So if you imagine the acceleration needed to going from v= 0 to v =1 for any dt-> 0 you can see that the acceleration needed is unbounded. So a ramped BC for your displacement would look like some sigmoid function.
ok, I get this part. But why the fluctuation of velocity keeps to exist after the displacement is almost fixed?

It's been a while since I looked at this problem, but when you do the math for a simple problem, I think you will be able to see why.  Do the first few time steps manually for a problem with IC = 0 for displacement and velocity. The whole block then has a BC on displacement such that disp = t. When you write out these equations, you should see that how the acceleration and velocity is calculated the velocity will oscillate.

node.title: section '[FluidProperty]' does not have an associated "Action".
node.bodyText:
hello,everyone! I'm trying to develop an application, in which the Water97FluidProperties is used. But after the "FluidProperties" block is included in the input file, it runs into an error like "section '[FluidProperty]' does not have an associated "Action"." How can I solve this problem? Thanks very much!

1dpipeT97.txt

Hello
It should be [FluidProperties] not FluidProperty

Thanks! I've tried that and it didn't work. I've also tried to set [FluidProperties] as a sub-block of [Modules], which didn't work either. I'm wondering if I need some settings like a specific "action" or turn on a switch in the Makefile to use the [FluidProperties] in an inputfile? Thanks for your patience!
You also need to turn in the fluid properties module in the Makefile , then make clobberall and recompile
I cleared the build directory and recompiled, then it didn't give this error reporting again. Thank you very much!

node.title: How to Restart with the Tensor Mechanics Master Action System
node.bodyText:
Hello!
I am currently working on a two-step solid mechanics simulation, where the stress distribution obtained from the first simulation is mapped to a second model for further computation (both models share identical meshes). I am encountering two issues and would appreciate your assistance:


In the first simulation, I used [Modules/TensorMechanics/Master/all] as shown below. However, I am not sure how to carry over the stress components into the second simulation using something similar to initial_from_file_var.
Is it necessary to record all stress components in AuxVariables and AuxKernels in the first simulation to achieve this restarting?
Sorry that I couldn’t find clear parameters in the documentation for the Tensor Mechanics Master Action System or Restarting and recovering from previous simulations.
I wanted to try with initial_from_file_var and initial_from_file_timestep in this block, but the error below actually becomes an obstacle.


While running the 2nd simulation using the  the following .i file, I encountered an error that left me puzzled:



OnlyMicro80nmRestart.i:34: missing required parameter 'Modules/TensorMechanics/Master/displacements'
Doc String: "The nonlinear displacement variables for the problem."

I actually specified displacements = 'ux uy uz' as shown by the attached part of my .i file, but the error persists. (I should make it clear that I did not set the displacements in my 1st simulation, so when the error occurs I added this line, but still the same error.)
Thank you for your help in advance and look forward to your reply!
Best regards,
Daijun
> [Mesh]
>     file = OnlyMicro80nm_out.e
>     distribution = serial
> []
> 
> [Problem]
>   restart_file_base = OnlyMicro80nm_outcp/LATEST
>   force_restart = false
> []
> 
> [Variables]
>   [./ux]
>     order = FIRST
>     family = LAGRANGE
>     initial_from_file_var = ux
>     initial_from_file_timestep = 635
>   [../]
> 
>   [./uy]
>     order = FIRST
>     family = LAGRANGE
>     initial_from_file_var = uy
>     initial_from_file_timestep = 635
>   [../]
> 
>   [./uz]
>     order = FIRST
>     family = LAGRANGE
>     initial_from_file_var = uz
>     initial_from_file_timestep = 635
>   [../]
> []
> 
> [Modules/TensorMechanics/Master/all]
>   strain = FINITE
>   displacements = 'ux uy uz'
>   add_variables = true
>   generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_yy stress_zz stress_xy stress_xz stress_yz strain_xx strain_yy strain_zz strain_xy strain_xz strain_yz'
> []
> 
> [AuxVariables]
>   [./slip_increment_1]
>    order = FIRST
>    family = MONOMIAL
>     initial_from_file_var = slip_increment_1
>     initial_from_file_timestep = 635
>   [../]
> []

Hello
The stresses are material properties which are not restarted using ICs or using initial_from_file_var parameters.
Your best bet is to use Checkpoint restart
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_usage/restart_recover.html
This second error will likely go away if you switched your syntax to the Physics syntax.
If it does not, it's asking for diplacements to be nested under Master/ instead of under Master/all
Guillaume

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for your reply!
I will try the Physics syntax for the 2nd error.
I am still a bit confused about the Tensor Mechanics Master Action. On the webpage https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Modules/TensorMechanics/Master/index.html, it is mentioned that it generates aux variables and auxkernels to aid in the output of tensor components. So I think those stress components I added in generate_output = 'stress_xx strain_xx' are not material properties, but a kind of AuxVariables and AuxKernels calculated based on the solid mechanics equations, which should follow the restarting methods of AuxVariables. If I use Checkpoint restart, will all these outputs be automatically inherited into new simulations from the checkpoint file?
If so, is strain_xx inheritable? Because I have chosen in Variables to let the displacement inherit the previous simulation, so the strain should be recalculated based on the displacement field at the beginning of the second simulation?
I'm a bit confused about this, before the Tensor Mechanics Master Action setting came out, I thought my strategy would be to create AuxVaribales and AuxKernels for each stress component and use initial_from_file_var, but not do this for strain_xx since the displacement field is already inherited  .  Now after using Master/all I am a little confused about this.
I hope you can clear it up for me, thank you very much!
Best regards,
Daijun
these auxiliary variables are only there for visualization purposes. In the equations, the stress/strain material properties are used

so the strain should be recalculated based on the displacement field at the beginning of the second simulation?

it probably should but it's not that simple because there are often history effects (plasticity!) in solid mechanics. So the material properties are not restarted that way. They are restarted properly only using Checkpoint

Thank you for your answer!
If displacements and strain fields are inherited separately, that is, the strain field is inherited as a material property, and the displacement field is inherited manually in  Variables and cannot reflect the historical effect, are there any incompatible parts among them?
The displacement field cannot reflect whether there is plasticity in it, but it should still be able to make the material enter the plastic segment according to the material constitutive model we set, becaue the calculation is often driven by the displacements. Is this  a kind of duplication or conflict with the inheritance of the strain field?

if you use checkpoint to inherit both, displacements and strain will be consistent.
If you use checkpoint for strain and set the displacements differently, using ICs or another file (with the SolutionUO for example), then they wont be consistent and the results will be affected.

node.title: Finite Strain and in echelon dynamics test
node.bodyText:
Hello,
We have trouble working with dynamics in finite strains when using initial conditions on displacement. In fact we can see the correct displacement at the first increment while the strain and stress computations are wrong. This in echelon test works fine in small strain even when coupled with phase field fracture. I wonder if it's because of the strain initialization at the ComputeFiniteStrain ? Thanks for any help.
Any help on this issue ?

When using an initial condition like :
[Variables]
  [./disp_x]
  [./InitialCondition]
      type = FunctionIC
      function = initial_cond_func_x
    [../]
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
  [./InitialCondition]
      type = FunctionIC
      function = initial_cond_func_y
    [../]
  [../]
[]

[Functions]
[./initial_cond_func_x]
    type = SolutionFunction
    solution = s0
    from_variable = 'disp_x'
[../]
 [./initial_cond_func_y]
    type = SolutionFunction
    solution = s0
    from_variable = 'disp_y'
[../]
[]

[UserObjects]
  [./s0]
    type = SolutionUserObject
    mesh = Finitehalf_elastic_960_out.e #half_elastic_960_out.e
    timestep = LATEST
    execute_on = initial
  [../]
[]

And with the Material block as:

    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    youngs_modulus = 3.09e9
    poissons_ratio = 0.35
  [../]
[./elasticStrain]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  [../]
[]

We got correct displacements but stress and strain are null which is strange.
could this be due to the initialization in the 'ComputeFiniteStrain.C' or 'ComputeIncrementalStrainBase.C'

Hello
You need to use a proper restart using Checkpoints to restart stateful material properties.
You can't use solution user objects to restart just some variables. Unless you put in more objects from the ProjectedMaterialPropertyStorage (or some name like this) action.

Ok thanks! I did this using Checkpoint and restart_file_base but I got this error:
*** ERROR ***
The stateful material property 'elastic_strain' was declared in ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress "elasticStrain" but was not declared in that object on checkpoint.

This is not currently supported due to ambiguity.

Please contact the development team on GitHub if you desire this capability.

I don't even understand what this capability is. Both the original file and the new restart file have a ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress object.
Does it have exactly the same name? And same suffix/prefix (if those are used) for material properties?

Now the error is :
*** ERROR ***
The stateful material properties in ComputeLinearElasticPFFractureStress "elastic" that are being restarted do not match the stored properties in the same material object from the checkpoint.

Checkpointed stateful properties:
 - hist

Current stateful properties:
 - hist
 - stress

We use the same material in both computations.

Some option must be different.
Can you paste the Materials and GlobalParams blocks in both simulations?

Everything is the same only the Modules:
The first (to import) is quasistatic:
[Physics/SolidMechanics/QuasiStatic]
  [all]
    strain = small 
    add_variables = true
    extra_vector_tags = 'kernel_residual'
    additional_generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_xy stress_yy'
  []
[]


and the main that imports :
[Modules]
  [./TensorMechanics/DynamicMaster]
      [all]
        add_variables = true
        hht_alpha =-0.333
        newmark_beta = 0.44 #0.3025
        newmark_gamma =0.83
        strain = small 
        density = 1180 
        additional_generate_output = 'stress_yy stress_xy stress_xx'
       extra_vector_tags = 'kernel_residual'
      []
